results.title: Taking control
results.description:
The women in Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman seek their own justice because society won’t believe or listen to them. When the system fails, they fight back. The characters on this screen are part of that cinematic tradition, which stretches from exploitation films like Foxy Brown (1974) and Ms .45 (1982) to today. In that time, female characters have triumphed despite being disbelieved. Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) could have avoided killing the queen in Aliens (1986) if the men in the first film had listened to her warnings. In Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991), Sarah Connor has to escape an asylum because no one believes she averted an AI apocalypse in the first film.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. Law and Order: SVU’s Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) puts the “lights out” of her attacker but also fights for victims, while Once Were Warriors (1994) follows Beth (Rena Owen) learning she can “survive anything” after tragedy. In A Fantastic Woman (2017), a trans woman battles a legal system that discriminates against her and in Total Control (2019–) Senator Alex Irving (Deborah Mailman) stands up to her political opponents, knowing her push for social justice is “bigger” than their rivalry.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. results.title: [Release prints compilation]
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)

results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This work presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: Let's not say goodbye
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: The destruction of Australia’s bushland and forests threatens already endangered species. Members of the Theatre in Education and the Real Fantasy Theatre Company take a humorous look at this serious problem.

results.title: I am a dancer
results.creator_credit: Pierre Jourdan, Evdoros Demetriou, Demetrion Productions and Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais
results.brief_description: Rudolf Nureyev is considered one of the world’s greatest dancers and this documentary provides an insight to the man, his work and his passion for the art of ballet. Includes segments from four ballets with partners Margot Fonteyn (Marguerite and Armand), Carla Fracci, (La Sylphide), Lynn Seymour (The Sleeping beauty), and Deanne Bergsma (Field figures). A French/British co-production with narration by Bryan Forbes.

results.title: The Shillingbury blowers
results.creator_credit: Val Guest, Greg Smith and Inner Circle Films
results.brief_description: A tale about a quaint English village and its community Brass Band known as the Shillingbury Blowers led by its much loved conductor, Old Saltie (Trevor Howard). Tells of how this rather old-fashioned and conventional village is turned on its head when young pop musician Peter Higgins (Robin Nedwell) and his wife Sally (Diane Keen) move into town. Cast includes Jack Douglas, John Le Mesurier, Patrick Newell, Diane King. Music composed and conducted by Ed Welch.

results.title: The Other sister
results.creator_credit: Garry Marshall, Alex Rose, Mario Iscovich and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: When a mentally challenged young woman returns home from an institution, she craves independence not willingly granted by her loving but overprotective mother. After meeting a mentally handicapped man, Carla experiences romance and the desire for a life unencumbered by others’ limited expectations of her. Cast includes Juliette Lewis, Diane Keaton, Tom Skerritt, Giovanni Ribisi, Poppy Montgomery, Juliet Mills.

results.title: Horowitz in Moscow
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Robert Dalrymple, Camivideo and Columbia Artists
results.brief_description: This video celebrates the return of Vladimir Horowitz to his home country, the Soviet Union, in 1986 to perform a musical recital at the Moscow Conservatory. It was to be the first important event in a series of cultural exchanges agreed to at the Geneva Summit in 1985. Horowitz calls himself an “ambassador of peace” as he talks to the media, his fans and his family. The biographical documentary captures the emotions of both Horowitz and his adoring fans as he performs some of his favourite compositions by such composers as Mozart, Chopin and Rachmaninov, among others. Interspersed throughout this demanding performance are images of Moscow, the people, streets and cityscape along with insightful interviews with Horowitz as he reminisces about his past. An absorbing and thoughtful documentary featuring some wonderful solo music played by one of the world’s best and highly regarded pianists.

results.title: The Rocky Horror picture show
results.creator_credit: Jim Sharman, Michael White and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The film begins with our innocent pair of lovers, Brad and Janet, stranded in a rain storm with the only available shelter being the weird Dr. Frank N. Furter mansion. Before the night is out Brad and Janet will lose their respective virginities to the Doctor, be introduced to his muscle-bound creation, Rocky, and battle the evil beings from the planet Transylvania. The plot is ridiculous, the music enjoyable and the whole thing is an outrageously good time. Possibly the most popular cult movie of all time and based on the original stage musical by Richard O’Brien. With Richard O’Brien, Susan Sarandon, Nell Campbell and Patricia Quinn all doing the “Time warp”. Tim Curry steals the show with an over-the-top performance as the sex mad Doctor.

results.title: Insomnia (1997)
results.creator_credit: Erik Skjoldbjaerg, Petter Borgli, Tom Remlov, Tomas Backstrom, Nordic Screen Production AS and Norsk Film
results.brief_description: Edgy police thriller set in Norway and the original version of this title. A police detective (Stellan Skarsgard) is flown in from Sweeden to a small rural town in Norway to help solve the murder of a teenage schoolgirl. In pursuit of the suspect in deep fog, his partner is shot and the accident leads the murderer to blackmail the detective. Due to the Midnight Sun and the stress of the situation he finds himself in, the detective suffers from insomnia which impacts on his judgement in dealing with his partner’s death. Tense and brooding the film questions the role of police as the enforcers of the law when they themselves are not above its constructs. Co-written and directed by Erik Skjoldbjaerg this is a compelling first-time feature. Cast includes Sverre Anker Ousdal, Bjorn Floberg, Gisken Armand, Maria Bonnevie.
